newsitem.title: UK: S&P rates Platinum Technology B plus.
newsitem.headline: S&P rates Platinum Technology B plus.

text.p: Standard & Poor's said on Thursday it had assigned Platinum Technology a corporate credit rating of B plus.
At the same time S&P said it had assigned Platinum Technology's $85 million convertible subordinated notes due 2001, a B minus rating.
"The outlook is negative," S&P said in a statement.

"The ratings could be lowered if the company does not achieve and maintain profitable operations over the near term as factored into the current ratings, or adopt a growth strategy to preserve appropriate credit protection measures for its current rating," S&P said.
"The ratings reflect Platinum Technology's aggressive growth, historical losses, and the significant challenges to integrate acquired operations," S&P said.
It said Oakbrook Terrace, Illinois based Platinum Technology provided systems management tools, database utilities and data warehousing products.

"The company addresses fast-growing markets, but faces technology risks, and competitive threats from established, better-financed competitors," the agency said. "Research and development expense is expected to remain above industry averages due to the company's strategy of supporting a broad product offering across multiple computing environments."
Additionally, S&P said operating margins, currently in the 6.0 percent area, had been pressured due to heavy investment in sales and marketing.
"Standard & Poor's expects profitability to improve over the the next 12 months as the sales force becomes more productive, acquisitions are digested, and the revenue base expands," S&P said.
Platinum Technology has moderate capital requirements. Existing cash balances and growing cash flow should support a moderate-sized acquisition programme without affecting credit quality, S&P said.
